speaker: James
text: [dry] So, Cassandra. Daughter of Priam, prophetess of doom, utterly unheeded. Sound familiar?

speaker: Elena
text: Are we really equating climate scientists to a mythical Trojan princess now? That feels a bit dramatic.

speaker: James
text: The article does. And the core argument is less about drama, more about the brutal reality: it's too late for prevention.

speaker: Elena
text: Too late? That's a surrender, James. We have the data, we know the drivers.

speaker: James
text: [emphatic] The data shows we're already locked into a 1.6 degrees Celsius global temperature rise. Locked in.

speaker: Elena
text: 1.6? But the international agreements, Paris... that was for keeping us under two.

speaker: James
text: Aspirational. Cumulative emissions are a physical fact. We've emitted too much already.

speaker: Elena
text: But 'no viable political solution'? That's a strong claim.

speaker: James
text: To stay below two degrees, we'd need to stop *all* greenhouse gas emissions immediately. Every single one. Globally.

speaker: Elena
text: That's an impossible ask, obviously.

speaker: James
text: Exactly. So, the political solution isn't going to happen.

speaker: Elena
text: No, that's completely wrong, and I'll tell you why. Incremental change, huge investment in renewables...

speaker: James
text: Incremental won't reverse the cumulative effect fast enough. We've had thirty years since Rio.

speaker: Elena
text: So all that effort was pointless?

speaker: James
text: [sardonic] Ineffectual, certainly, if the goal was to avoid the 1.6-degree lock-in.

speaker: Elena
text: I think you're cherry-picking. The 'renewables and battery revolution' article painted a far more hopeful picture.

speaker: James
text: Hope is one thing. The scale and speed of global coordination required is another. Look at the grid problems for 'European Electricity Utilities'.

speaker: Elena
text: But individual nations *can* act. They can set price floors for energy, they can build new infrastructure.

speaker: James
text: They can. But the article's core point: international institutions — UN, WTO, World Bank — won't survive the turmoil.

speaker: Elena
text: Collapse? That's a huge leap. These structures have weathered storms before.

speaker: James
text: They rely on stability. Climate change will unleash instability on a scale the 20th-century models just can't handle.

speaker: Elena
text: So, every nation for itself? That's exactly the kind of thinking that got us into this mess!

speaker: James
text: It's pragmatic. When the global food supply chain breaks, as HFN warned in 'Consequences of Inaction', nations will prioritise their own.

speaker: Elena
text: But that's an abdication of shared responsibility. The 'immorality of climate change' piece made a powerful case for global solidarity.

speaker: James
text: [thoughtful] I don't want to agree with you on this, but the numbers don't leave much room. If 1.6 degrees is baked in, and we won't stop emitting globally...

speaker: Elena
text: Well, okay, if the 1.6 degrees is truly unavoidable, then yes, adaptation is critical.

speaker: James
text: And the article suggests we're heading for 3, 4, or 5 degrees, not just 1.6.

speaker: Elena
text: Wait, really? What pushes it beyond the already locked-in figure?

speaker: James
text: Because we won't cease emitting. It's a treadmill, Elena. You called it that yourself.

speaker: Elena
text: I did. A treadmill. Okay, I see that. It compounds.

speaker: James
text: So, national planning. Prioritising your country, then your region. Food security, energy independence.

speaker: Elena
text: But the erosion of international law, the breakdown of global cooperation... that's truly terrifying.

speaker: James
text: [conceding] It's not a pleasant outlook. But if those institutions aren't robust enough, they'll collapse anyway.

speaker: Elena
text: So we just... prepare for it? No effort to prop them up?

speaker: James
text: The effort, the article implies, is now best directed at national resilience. Hope for the best, plan for the worst.

speaker: Elena
text: And the worst involves every nation for itself, sacrificing global good for local survival.

speaker: James
text: Shared responsibility becomes a luxury when the harvests fail and the grid goes down.

speaker: Elena
text: [clipped] A bleak future, James. Cassandra was right, then.

speaker: James
text: She usually is. It's the belief, or lack thereof, that defines the outcome.
